title: Jimmy Beasley
text:
James Edward Beasley (born September 30, 1931) is an American <a href="rhythm%20and%20blues">rhythm and blues</a> singer, pianist and songwriter.
Born in <a href="Kansas%20City%2C%20Missouri">Kansas City, Missouri</a>, Beasley learned piano from Willie Rice, and was heavily influenced by <a href="Fats%20Domino">Fats Domino</a>. He was also a <a href="Golden%20Gloves">Golden Gloves</a> winning <a href="amateur%20boxer">amateur boxer</a>, and sang in the Aces Quartet and the Sonny Kenner Trio. In 1954, he moved to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, and joined <a href="King%20Perry">King Perry</a>'s band, with whom he recorded for <a href="Hollywood%20Records">Hollywood Records</a>. He also recorded under his own name for the <a href="Peacock%20Records">Peacock</a> and <a href="Modern%20Records">Modern</a> labels, in a style similar to Fats Domino.
Although Beasley had no national chart hits, "Ella Jane", recorded with a band that included saxophonists <a href="Maxwell%20Davis">Maxwell Davis</a> and <a href="Plas%20Johnson">Plas Johnson</a>, and guitarist <a href="Rene%20Hall">Rene Hall</a>, sold moderately well, and Beasley regularly played in Los Angeles clubs. Some of Beasley's recordings on Modern, including "Don't Feel Sorry for Me" and "Little Coquette" were recorded in <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> in 1956 with <a href="Dave%20Bartholomew">Dave Bartholomew</a>'s band, and "Little Coquette" was later recorded by Fats Domino. Beasley also backed <a href="Etta%20James">Etta James</a> at recording sessions in New Orleans.
After having a moderate regional hit with "My Happiness" in 1956, Beasley formed his own band and moved to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, where he worked for <a href="Alan%20Freed">Alan Freed</a>, performed alongside <a href="Ray%20Charles">Ray Charles</a>, <a href="Elvis%20Presley">Elvis Presley</a> and <a href="Ruth%20Brown">Ruth Brown</a>, appeared on numerous TV shows, and continued to write for Fats Domino and others. He continued to record for Modern and its subsidiary <a href="Crown%20Records">Crown</a> label, who released an <a href="LP%20record">LP</a>, "Jimmy's House Party", which was repackaged in 1961 with a slightly different track listing as "Twist with Jimmy Beasley". His last recordings, "Ready To Go" / "My Baby's Gone", were released in 1965. His records were among those that influenced the development of <a href="ska">ska</a> music in <a href="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>.
In the 1970s, Beasley appeared in cabaret in <a href="Reno">Reno</a> and <a href="Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</a>, and regularly in <a href="Laughlin%2C%20Nevada">Laughlin, Nevada</a>. He then moved to <a href="Torrance%2C%20California">Torrance, California</a>, where he owned a club and continued to perform occasionally. He also appeared at blues festivals in Europe in the 1990s, but retired from performing after a <a href="stroke">stroke</a> in the late 1990s.
